feed.title: Management of stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: We share the philosophy of the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) that pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic therapies should be guided by disease severity and aim to control symptoms, decrease exacerbations, and improve patient function and quality of life.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: Both pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic interventions are key to the management of COPD patients.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: In the discussion that follows, the formal assessment of COPD severity, the various therapies for COPD, and the clinical evidence for each therapy are reviewed.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: However, for patients who present with severe disease, a stepwise approach may not always be the best choice, as it may be necessary to initiate several medications at once to achieve symptom control.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: An approach to the management of patients with stable COPD is outlined below.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: The oral bronchodilator theophylline, which is only modestly effective and has more side effects than inhaled bronchodilators, is occasionally used for patients with refractory COPD;

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: Mucoactive agents are now rarely used and chronic systemic glucocorticoids are not recommended.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: Smoking cessation is a crucial step in the management of all patients with COPD.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: Pulmonary rehabilitation also has a major role in the management of COPD, and supplemental oxygen therapy improves mortality in patients with significant hypoxemia at rest.

section.label: GENERAL APPROACH
section.fragment: In order to determine whether the patient has achieved an adequate response to therapy, it is necessary to monitor symptoms (dyspnea, activity tolerance), the amount of as-needed medication use, health status, the frequency of exacerbations, and lung function (ie, airflow limitation on spirometry).

section.label: ASSESSING DISEASE SEVERITY
section.fragment: A multi-component staging system for COPD severity has been developed by the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) that categorizes disease severity based on (1) symptoms (based on modified Medical Research Council dyspnea scale or COPD Assessment Test [CAT]), (2) the severity of airflow limitation (based on the forced expiratory volume in one second [FEV 1] percent predicted) among patients with a ratio of FEV1 to forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC) <0.7, and (3) risk of exacerbations.

section.label: ASSESSING DISEASE SEVERITY
section.fragment: This categorization system is also used as a guide for the management of patients with stable COPD.

section.label: ASSESSING DISEASE SEVERITY
section.fragment: The multidimensional BODE index may be used to assess an individual's risk of death or hospitalization due to COPD );

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS
section.fragment: Bronchodilators are the therapeutic mainstay for patients with COPD.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS
section.fragment: Bronchodilators have been consistently shown to induce long-term improvements in symptoms, exercise capacity, and airflow limitation, even when there is no spirometric improvement following a single test dose.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS
section.fragment: All symptomatic patients with COPD should be prescribed a short-acting bronchodilator to be used on an as-needed basis.

section.label: acting bronchodilators
section.fragment: The first decision that most clinicians face when managing a patient with COPD is which short-acting bronchodilator is most appropriate in a patient with mild intermittent symptoms.

section.label: acting bronchodilators
section.fragment: All of the short-acting bronchodilators improve lung function and symptoms.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: In general, short-acting beta agonists are prescribed on an as-needed basis, rather than regularly scheduled, in order to decrease sympathomimetic exposure in patients with less severe symptoms.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: One trial randomly assigned 53 patients with COPD to receive regularly scheduled albuterol or placebo, while continuing ipratropium bromide, inhaled glucocorticoid, and as-needed albuterol.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: Regularly scheduled albuterol doubled the total amount of albuterol received without a clinically significant impact on lung function, symptoms, or exercise capacity.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: However, in a nested case control study of 76,661 patients with COPD, the rate of severe cardiac arrhythmia was elevated among those with new use of oral or inhaled short-acting beta agonist (RR 1.27, 95% CI 1.03-1.57).

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: Hypokalemia can also occur in extreme cases and should be monitored in patients at risk.

section.label: Anticholinergics
section.fragment: Short-acting anticholinergic medications improve lung function and symptoms.

section.label: Anticholinergics
section.fragment: As an example, one double-blind trial randomly assigned 183 patients with moderate to severe COPD to receive ipratropium alone (80 mcg, three times per day), formoterol, or placebo for 12 weeks.

section.label: Anticholinergics
section.fragment: Short-acting beta agonists were permitted as-needed for relief of acute dyspnea.

section.label: Comparison
section.fragment: On average, both medications improve lung function to a similar degree.

section.label: Combination therapy
section.fragment: As an example, the largest trial randomly assigned 534 patients with COPD to receive albuterol alone, ipratropium alone, or combination therapy (albuterol plus ipratropium).

section.label: Combination therapy
section.fragment: A similar study reported that combination therapy decreased the frequency of exacerbation compared to albuterol, but not ipratropium.

section.label: acting bronchodilators
section.fragment: Short-acting bronchodilators alone or in combination may be insufficient to control symptoms and are not considered to be maintenance therapies.

section.label: acting bronchodilators
section.fragment: A regularly scheduled long-acting inhaled bronchodilator is added in these patients, who have more advanced disease in the range of GOLD category B and higher.

section.label: acting bronchodilators
section.fragment: The use of theophylline is usually limited to an add-on therapy when symptoms continue in patients with more severe disease despite the use of other treatments.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: Multiple studies have demonstrated the benefit of LABAs in patients with stable COPD.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: The largest trial of salmeterol, Toward a Revolution in COPD Health (TORCH), randomly assigned 6112 patients with mostly severe COPD (mean FEV1 44 percent of predicted ) to one of four treatment arms for three years: salmeterol alone (50 mcg twice daily), fluticasone alone (500 mcg twice daily), combination therapy (salmeterol plus fluticasone), or placebo.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: The potential association of hospitalization or death due to a cardiac arrhythmia and use of LABAs was examined in a nested case control study of 76,661 patients aged >=67 years with COPD.

section.label: Beta agonists
section.fragment: The largest trial randomly assigned 1683 patients with moderate-to-severe COPD to once daily indacaterol 150 or 300 mcg, placebo, or tiotropium.

section.label: Anticholinergics
section.fragment: Tiotropium, which has been studied the most, improves lung function and decreases dynamic hyperinflation (an effect also seen with other medications), while also decreasing dyspnea and exacerbations.

section.label: Anticholinergics
section.fragment: Conflicting evidence has suggested possible adverse cardiovascular effects of anticholinergic therapy in patients with COPD.

section.label: Anticholinergics
section.fragment: However, a large randomized trial, the TIOtropium Safety and Performance In Respimat (TIOSPIR) trial, revealed no safety issues with the device and is reassuring about the safety of the Respimat device.

section.label: Comparison
section.fragment: In a nested case-control analysis, 26,628 patients age 66 or older with COPD who had a hospitalization or emergency room visit for a cardiovascular event were matched to controls with similar age and COPD severity who had no cardiovascular events.

section.label: Combined therapy
section.fragment: In patients with GOLD stage II-IV COPD whose symptoms are not well-controlled with a single long-acting bronchodilator, the addition of a second class of long acting bronchodilator may provide additional benefit.

section.label: Combined therapy
section.fragment: A meta-analysis of five trials (3263 participants) that assessed combination therapy with tiotropium (LAMA) plus a LABA (salmeterol, formoterol, or indacaterol) and found only a slightly better quality of life and a small increase in the post-bronchodilator FEV1 with the combination compared with tiotropium alone.

section.label: INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: Inhaled glucocorticoids (also known as inhaled corticosteroids or ICS) may reduce this inflammation.

section.label: INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: The available data, which are presented in detail separately, suggest that inhaled glucocorticoids decrease exacerbations and modestly slow the progression of respiratory symptoms, but appear to have little impact on lung function and mortality.

section.label: INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: Adverse effects associated with inhaled glucocorticoids are discussed separately.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: Inhaled glucocorticoids are typically used in combination with a long-acting bronchodilator for patients in GOLD stage III-IV, who have significant symptoms or repeated exacerbations, despite an optimal bronchodilator regimen.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: Inhaled glucocorticoids are continued in patients whose symptoms, frequency of exacerbations, and/or lung function improve within one month.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: Estimates of cost-effectiveness also favored the salmeterol-fluticasone combination over placebo or either of the individual agents.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: The second large trial of combination therapy (Investigating New Standards for Prophylaxis in Reduction of Exacerbations, INSPIRE) included 1323 patients with stable, mostly severe COPD (mean FEV1 39 percent of predicted ) who were randomly assigned to receive salmeterol plus fluticasone (50 and 500 microg/puff, respectively) or tiotropium alone for two years.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: Whether a lower strength preparation of fluticasone would have a similarly beneficial effect on mortality without the adverse effect on pneumonia is not known, although a prior study using the 250 microg strength of fluticasone in combination with salmeterol reported a similar increase in the number of pneumonias compared with salmeterol alone.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of COPD.

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: In a pooled analysis of two trials that compared combinations of vilanterol-fluticasone with vilanterol alone in 3255 patients with COPD, vilanterol 25 mcg with fluticasone 100 mcg or 200 mcg modestly reduced the yearly moderate and severe exacerbation rates more than vilanterol alone (RR 0.79, 95% CI 0.64-0.97, RR 0.69, 95% CI 0.56-0.85, respectively).

section.label: BRONCHODILATORS PLUS INHALED GLUCOCORTICOIDS
section.fragment: A question that has been less well studied is whether it would be preferable to add a second long-acting bronchodilator (from the alternate class) or an inhaled glucocorticoid in patients whose disease in not well-controlled with a single long-acting bronchodilator.

section.label: TRIPLE INHALER THERAPY
section.fragment: In patients with severe COPD, triple inhaler therapy with a long-acting beta agonist plus an inhaled glucocorticoid plus a long-acting anticholinergic is often used.

section.label: TRIPLE INHALER THERAPY
section.fragment: with two-thirds of the patients using an inhaled long acting beta agonist (LABA) and an inhaled glucocorticoid (ICS) as their usual care.

section.label: TRIPLE INHALER THERAPY
section.fragment: The addition of tiotropium to those patients receiving a LABA and an ICS as usual care significantly improved airflows, reduced exacerbations, and improved health related quality of life.

section.label: TRIPLE INHALER THERAPY
section.fragment: A retrospective study of two cohorts of patients with COPD cared for in the Veterans Affairs (VA) system compared a regimen of tiotropium plus inhaled LABA plus ICS to a historic, matched COPD population treated with an inhaled LABA plus ICS.

section.label: TRIPLE INHALER THERAPY
section.fragment: Other studies have shown a benefit to triple therapy compared with single agent therapy in moderate to severe COPD: In a double-blind trial, 449 patients with moderate or severe COPD were randomly assigned to one of three treatment groups: tiotropium plus placebo, tiotropium plus salmeterol, or tiotropium plus both salmeterol and fluticasone for one year;

section.label: REFRACTORY DISEASE
section.fragment: Some patients continue to have symptoms or repeated exacerbations of COPD despite therapy with an optimal long-acting inhaled bronchodilator plus an inhaled glucocorticoid (eg, GOLD III or IV).

section.label: REFRACTORY DISEASE
section.fragment: When managing patients with refractory disease, we assess for exercise-related oxygen desaturation using pulse oximetry during ambulation.

section.label: REFRACTORY DISEASE
section.fragment: If desaturation occurs and is associated with symptoms, use of supplemental oxygen may reduce symptoms.

section.label: REFRACTORY DISEASE
section.fragment: A small number of carefully selected patients may benefit from surgical intervention.

section.label: Theophylline
section.fragment: Similarly, in a randomized crossover trial of 60 patients with COPD, theophylline decreased dyspnea and improved gas exchange, lung function, and respiratory muscle function.

section.label: Theophylline
section.fragment: Theophylline is metabolized in the liver and any process that interferes with liver function can rapidly change theophylline levels.

section.label: Theophylline
section.fragment: In addition, many drugs can interact with theophylline, requiring close monitoring of drug levels and awareness of these issues.

section.label: Theophylline
section.fragment: In general, patients with COPD can be adequately treated with serum levels in the 8 to 12 mcg/mL range.

section.label: 4 inhibitors
section.fragment: Roflumilast is an oral, PDE-4 inhibitor that is approved for use in patients with COPD.

section.label: 4 inhibitors
section.fragment: The FDA approved indication is for the reduction of exacerbations in patients with chronic bronchitis, severe or very severe airflow limitation, and a history of exacerbations.

section.label: 4 inhibitors
section.fragment: Roflumilast significantly improved prebronchodilator FEV1 and decreased the rate of moderate to severe exacerbations in a 52 week, randomized trial of 3091 patients with COPD.

section.label: 4 inhibitors
section.fragment: Side effects of nausea, diarrhea, and weight loss were more frequent in the roflumilast groups.

section.label: 4 inhibitors
section.fragment: Although roflumilast is approved in the United States for COPD patients with a history of exacerbations, the magnitude of benefit on lung function is modest.

section.label: 4 inhibitors
section.fragment: Whether roflumilast provides additional benefits when combined with other respiratory medications (eg, LABA/inhaled glucocorticoid combination) that are used to reduce COPD exacerbation frequency remains unknown and is currently under investigation.

section.label: Systemic glucocorticoids
section.fragment: Systemic glucocorticoids have long been used to treat exacerbations in patients with COPD;

section.label: Systemic glucocorticoids
section.fragment: The roles of systemic glucocorticoids in the treatment of acute exacerbations of COPD and in chronic stable COPD are discussed in more detail separately.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: Thick, tenacious secretions can be a major problem in patients with COPD, but there is little evidence that thinning or increasing the clearance of secretions induces clinical improvement.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: Thus, mucoactive agents are not accepted as routine care for patients with stable COPD.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: Oral expectorants (eg, guaifenesin, iodides) offer little benefit to patients with COPD.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: As an example, one study demonstrated that iodinated glycerol improved cough and chest discomfort in some patients with chronic bronchitis;

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is a mucolytic that purportedly thins the secretions of patients with chronic bronchitis.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: Alternative mucolytics include dornase alfa (DNase), exogenous surfactant, various proteolytic agents, and various detergents.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: These agents require additional evaluation prior to their routine use in patients with COPD.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: Nebulized water or hypertonic saline is without documented benefit and may irritate the airways and induce bronchospasm.

section.label: Chronic antibiotic therapy
section.fragment: Chronic antibiotic therapy is generally not indicated for the majority of patients with stable COPD (eg, emphysema, chronic bronchitis).

section.label: Chronic antibiotic therapy
section.fragment: However, certain antibiotics, macrolides in particular, may have antiinflammatory effects in addition to their antibiotic effect.

section.label: Chronic antibiotic therapy
section.fragment: For patients who continue to have frequent exacerbations despite optimal therapy for COPD with bronchodilators and antiinflammatory agents, we suggest antibiotic prophylaxis with azithromycin.

section.label: Chronic antibiotic therapy
section.fragment: Patients whose COPD is associated with bronchiectasis may benefit from chronic antibiotic therapy.

section.label: Chronic antibiotic therapy
section.fragment: Nonimmunized patients with COPD who are at high risk for contracting influenza and/or have early acute influenza infections may benefit from antiviral therapy.

section.label: Oxygen
section.fragment: Many patients with stable severe COPD (especially GOLD Stage IV disease) have chronic hypoxemia.

section.label: Oxygen
section.fragment: It is important that this be detected because long-term oxygen therapy improves survival and quality of life in hypoxemic patients with COPD.

section.label: Oxygen
section.fragment: Long-term oxygen therapy should be prescribed for all stable patients with COPD who have chronic hypoxemia at rest (PaO2 <=55 mmHg or SpO2 <=88 percent).

section.label: Oxygen
section.fragment: Arterial blood gases and pulse oximetry are the only reliable methods of detecting hypoxemia in patients with COPD because most patients have few if any symptoms that can specifically be related to decreased oxygenation.

section.label: Oxygen
section.fragment: Supplemental oxygen is recommended for individuals whose in-flight PaO2 is expected to fall below 50 mmHg.

section.label: Smoking cessation
section.fragment: Encouraging smoking cessation is essential because smoking cessation can reduce the rate of FEV1 decline that exists in smokers with COPD.

section.label: Vaccinations
section.fragment: Infection is a common cause of COPD exacerbation.

section.label: Vaccinations
section.fragment: Vaccinations can prevent some infections and should be offered to patients with stable COPD: Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine should be offered to all patients with COPD.

section.label: Vaccinations
section.fragment: An annual influenza vaccine should be given to all patients, particularly those with COPD.

section.label: Vaccinations
section.fragment: In a randomized, placebo-controlled trial of 125 patients with COPD, vaccination reduced the incidence of influenza by 76 percent, regardless of the severity of underlying COPD.

section.label: Rehabilitation
section.fragment: Given these benefits, which have been shown to persist for up to 18 months, pulmonary rehabilitation should be considered as an addition to medication therapy for symptomatic patients who have GOLD Stage II, III, or IV COPD.

section.label: Patient education
section.fragment: Patient education is an important part of managing patients with COPD and is a routine component of pulmonary rehabilitation.

section.label: Nutrition
section.fragment: More than 30 percent of patients with severe COPD have protein-calorie malnutrition.

section.label: Nutrition
section.fragment: High caloric dietary supplements and megestrol acetate (Megace, an appetite stimulant) have been used in an effort to combat malnutrition.

section.label: Nutrition
section.fragment: Thus, it has been hypothesized that antioxidants may prevent disease progression.

section.label: Nutrition
section.fragment: However, controlled clinical trials are needed before antioxidant vitamins can be recommended for the routine management of patients with stable COPD.

section.label: SURGERY
section.fragment: Carefully selected patients may benefit from lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) or lung transplantation.

section.label: Lung volume reduction surgery
section.fragment: The National Emphysema Treatment Trial (NETT) enrolled 1218 patients with severe emphysema and compared lung volume reduction surgery (LVRS) to maximal medical therapy.

section.label: Lung volume reduction surgery
section.fragment: The efficacy of LVRS varied among patient groups, but there was an overall survival advantage that was most marked in patients with upper lobe emphysema and low exercise capacity.

section.label: Transplantation
section.fragment: It is important to define disease severity as precisely as possible in order to determine which patients have the most urgent need for lung transplantation and are likely to have the longest survival after transplantation.

section.label: Transplantation
section.fragment: Guidelines for timing a referral for a transplant evaluation for patients with COPD and emphysema due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency include: BODE index >5.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Opiates may be of benefit for relief of dyspnea in selected patients, such as those with dyspnea unresponsive to the conventional approaches described above.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: The optimal dose and timing of opiate medication for control of dyspnea in COPD are not known.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Forty-eight opiate-naive patients with dyspnea predominantly due to COPD were randomly assigned to oral morphine 20 mg sustained release once daily or placebo for four days.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Morphine was associated with significant improvements in dyspnea and sleep, although constipation was a substantial adverse effect.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: In a separate dose-ranging study among 48 patients, oral sustained release morphine at 10 mg per day provided relief of dyspnea in 19 patients, 20 mg provided relief in another 5, and 30 mg provided relief in 3.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Choices include short-acting preparations of morphine, hydromorphone, and oxycodone for chronic, persistent dyspnea and rapid onset agents such as fentanyl buccal or sublingual tablets for episodic dyspnea.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Anxiety, depression, and dyspnea are often intertwined and attempts to characterize which symptom is the dominant or primary problem for an individual patient can be difficult.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Indeed, hyperventilation from anxiety can often accentuate and occasionally overwhelm patients with dyspnea.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Pulmonary rehabilitation can lead to a major improvement in patients with dyspnea, anxiety, and depression and should be strongly considered, especially if the use of opiates is being considered.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: In addition, psychoactive agents and cognitive behavioral therapy can be helpful in selected patients with anxiety or depression.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Respiratory stimulants are not beneficial to these patients and can often accentuate dyspnea, even in those with hypercapnic COPD.

section.label: PALLIATIVE TREATMENT OF DYSPNEA
section.fragment: Patients with advanced COPD may also benefit from hospice care.

section.label: Antiproteases
section.fragment: Recognition of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency as a cause of emphysema increased awareness that an imbalance of various proteases and antiproteases can cause COPD.

section.label: Antiproteases
section.fragment: For patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, research suggests that infusions of pooled human plasma alpha-1 antitrypsin (so-called augmentation therapy) may slow the rate of disease progression.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: It can be used as a guide for the management of patients with stable COPD.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For all patients with COPD, we recommend that a short-acting bronchodilator (eg, beta-agonist, anticholinergic agent) be prescribed for use as-needed for relief of intermittent increases in dyspnea.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients on a long-acting anticholinergic agent, a short-acting beta agonist is generally used for quick relief of COPD symptoms.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients with COPD in whom intermittent short-acting bronchodilators are insufficient to control symptoms or who have other high-risk predictors, including severe or very severe airflow obstruction or two or more exacerbations in the previous year, we recommend adding a regularly scheduled long-acting inhaled bronchodilator.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients who continue to have symptoms or have repeated exacerbations despite an optimal long-acting inhaled bronchodilator regimen, we suggest adding an inhaled glucocorticoid.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We recommend long-term oxygen therapy in all patients with COPD who have chronic hypoxemia.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: All patients with COPD should be advised to quit smoking, educated about COPD, and given a yearly influenza vaccination.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: In addition, the pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine should be given to all patients with COPD.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Patients who continue to have significant symptoms despite the above interventions may be considered for surgical therapy.

feed.title: Management of acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

section.label: PRECIPITANTS
section.fragment: It is estimated that 70 to 80 percent of COPD exacerbations are due to respiratory infections.

section.label: PRECIPITANTS
section.fragment: Among the 550 patients having a COPD exacerbation, the prevalence of pulmonary embolism was 20 percent.

section.label: PRECIPITANTS
section.fragment: An important limitation of the meta-analysis was its inability to determine whether the pulmonary embolism was the cause of the COPD exacerbation, a result of the COPD exacerbation, or a mere bystander.

section.label: RISK FACTORS
section.fragment: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) may be an additional risk factor for COPD exacerbations.

section.label: RISK FACTORS
section.fragment: A similar observation was made in a case-control study that assessed the presence of GERD symptoms and frequency of COPD exacerbations in 80 patients with COPD.

section.label: RISK FACTORS
section.fragment: The presence of GERD symptoms was associated with an increased risk of COPD exacerbations (RR 6.55, 95% CI 1.86 to 23.11).

section.label: RISK FACTORS
section.fragment: In a follow-up to the ECLIPSE study, the potential role of pulmonary vascular disease as a risk factor for exacerbations was assessed by using computed tomography scans to compute the ratio of the diameter of the pulmonary artery to the diameter of the aorta (PA:A ratio).

section.label: RISK FACTORS
section.fragment: However, a ratio >1 suggests the presence of pulmonary hypertension, although it does not clarify the cause of pulmonary hypertension (eg, hypoxemia due to COPD or other lung disease, left heart failure, sleep apnea).

section.label: INITIAL EVALUATION
section.fragment: Several criteria for hospitalization were proposed in a 2004 position paper from the American Thoracic Society/European Respiratory Society (ATS/ERS): Inadequate response of symptoms to outpatient management.

section.label: INITIAL EVALUATION
section.fragment: Inability to eat or sleep due to symptoms.

section.label: INITIAL EVALUATION
section.fragment: A meta-analysis of seven of these trials noted that home care resulted in equivalent clinical outcomes and substantial cost savings compared to hospitalization.

section.label: INITIAL EVALUATION
section.fragment: Although care at home is feasible in highly selected patients without these characteristics, implementation requires a dedicated support team to conduct ongoing clinical assessments and provide home care.

section.label: TREATMENT GOALS
section.fragment: Optimizing lung function by administering bronchodilators and other pharmacologic agents.

section.label: OXYGEN THERAPY
section.fragment: There are numerous devices available to deliver supplemental oxygen during an acute exacerbation of COPD: Venturi masks are the preferred means of oxygen delivery because they permit a precise delivered fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2. Venturi masks can deliver an FiO 2 of 24, 28, 31, 35, 40, or 60 percent. Nasal cannulae can provide flow rates up to 6 L per minute with an associated FiO2 of approximately 40 percent. They are more comfortable and convenient for the patient, especially during oral feedings. When higher inspired concentrations of oxygen are needed, simple facemasks can provide an FiO2 up to 55 percent using flow rates of 6 to 10 L per minute. However, variations in minute ventilation and inconsistent entrainment of room air affect the FiO2 when simple facemasks (or nasal cannulae) are used.

section.label: OXYGEN THERAPY
section.fragment: Inability to correct hypoxemia with a relatively low FiO2 (eg, 4 L/min by nasal cannula or 35 percent by mask) should prompt consideration of pulmonary emboli, acute respiratory distress syndrome, pulmonary edema, or severe pneumonia as the cause of respiratory failure.

section.label: OXYGEN THERAPY
section.fragment: Hypercapnia is generally well tolerated in patients whose arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) is chronically elevated.

section.label: Beta adrenergic agonists
section.fragment: Inhaled short-acting beta adrenergic agonists (eg, albuterol) are the mainstay of therapy for an acute exacerbation of COPD because of their rapid onset of action and efficacy in producing bronchodilation.

section.label: Beta adrenergic agonists
section.fragment: We favor nebulized therapy because many patients with COPD have difficulty using proper MDI technique in the setting of an acute exacerbation.

section.label: Beta adrenergic agonists
section.fragment: Increasing the dose of nebulized albuterol to 5 mg does not have a significant impact on spirometry or clinical outcomes.

section.label: Beta adrenergic agonists
section.fragment: Patients with severe COPD are at risk for hypercapnia with administration of supplemental oxygen, so concern has been raised about the risk of hypercapnia during bronchodilator treatments using oxygen-driven nebulizers.

section.label: Beta adrenergic agonists
section.fragment: Parenteral use of these agents results in greater inotropic and chronotropic effects, which may cause arrhythmias or myocardial ischemia in susceptible individuals.

section.label: Anticholinergic agents
section.fragment: This is based on several studies that found that combination therapy produces bronchodilation in excess of that achieved by either agent alone in patients with a COPD exacerbation, an asthma exacerbation, or stable COPD.

section.label: Efficacy
section.fragment: Systemic glucocorticoids, when added to the bronchodilator therapies described above, improve symptoms and lung function, and decrease the length of hospital stay.

section.label: Efficacy
section.fragment: This was illustrated by a trial that randomly assigned 271 patients with a COPD exacerbation to receive either systemic glucocorticoids or placebo for up to two weeks.

section.label: Route
section.fragment: As an example, a randomized trial assigned 210 patients hospitalized with a COPD exacerbation to receive oral or intravenous prednisolone (60 mg daily) for five days and found no difference between the two groups in the rate of treatment failure, length of hospital stay, improvement in spirometry, or improvement in quality of life.

section.label: Route
section.fragment: However, intravenous glucocorticoids are typically administered to patients who present with a severe exacerbation, who respond poorly to oral glucocorticoids, who are unable to take oral medication, or who may have impaired absorption due to decreased splanchnic perfusion (eg, patients in shock).

section.label: Dose
section.fragment: As this was an observational study and did not include objective measures of airflow limitation, it is possible that less ill patients were more likely to receive oral treatment.

section.label: Dose
section.fragment: For patients with impending or actual acute respiratory failure due to a COPD exacerbation, most clinicians would use an intravenous formulation at a higher dose, such as the equivalent of methylprednisolone 60 mg intravenously, one to four times daily, although outcomes data to guide this practice are not available.

section.label: Duration
section.fragment: A trial performed subsequent to the systematic review, the Reduction in the Use of Corticosteroids in Exacerbated COPD (REDUCE) trial, randomly assigned 314 patients with acute exacerbations of COPD, of whom 289 required hospitalization, to prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 or 14 days.

section.label: Antibiotics
section.fragment: Antibiotics are indicated for many patients having a COPD exacerbation.

section.label: Mucoactive agents
section.fragment: The lack of efficacy of mucoactive agents in the treatment of COPD exacerbations was best demonstrated by a double-blind trial that randomly assigned 50 patients with a COPD exacerbation to receive N-acetylcysteine (600 mg, twice daily) or placebo for seven days.

section.label: Methylxanthines
section.fragment: Aminophylline and theophylline are NOT recommended for the treatment of acute exacerbations of COPD.

section.label: Noninvasive ventilation
section.fragment: It improves numerous clinical outcomes and is the preferred method of ventilatory support in many patients with an acute exacerbation of COPD.

section.label: Noninvasive ventilation
section.fragment: Optimal initial settings for NPPV have not been established.

section.label: Invasive ventilation
section.fragment: Invasive mechanical ventilation for acute respiratory failure due to a COPD exacerbation is discussed separately.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: Among 1016 patients with an acute exacerbation of COPD and a PaCO2 of 50 mmHg or more, the 6 and 12 month mortality rates were 33 and 43 percent, respectively.

section.label: PROGNOSIS
section.fragment: In a study of 260 patients admitted with a COPD exacerbation, the one year mortality was 28 percent.

section.label: PREVENTION
section.fragment: An action plan encourages early intervention by giving patients guidelines on how to recognize an exacerbation, how to change their medication regimen accordingly, and when to contact their healthcare provider.

section.label: PREVENTION
section.fragment: The effect of high dose vitamin D supplementation on the incidence of COPD exacerbations was assessed in patients with moderate or more severe COPD who were randomly assigned to take vitamin D 100,000 IU or placebo orally every four weeks for a year.

section.label: PREVENTION
section.fragment: However, patients with severe vitamin D deficiency (serum 25-[OH] D levels <10 ng/mL) at baseline had a significant reduction in exacerbations.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: An acute exacerbation of COPD is characterized by an acute increase in symptoms beyond normal day-to-day variation.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We recommend that all patients having a COPD exacerbation receive both an inhaled short-acting beta adrenergic agonist and an inhaled short-acting anticholinergic agent, rather than either medication alone.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We recommend that all patients having a COPD exacerbation receive systemic glucocorticoids.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Antibiotics are indicated for many patients having a COPD exacerbation.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Mucoactive agents, mechanical techniques to augment sputum clearance, and methylxanthines have not been shown to confer benefit for patients with a COPD exacerbation.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: We suggest that all patients who are hypoxemic be given supplemental oxygen targeting a PaO2 of 60 to 70 mmHg, with an oxyhemoglobin saturation of 90 to 94 percent.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) improves numerous clinical outcomes and is the preferred method of ventilatory support in many patients with an acute exacerbation of COPD.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Invasive mechanical ventilation is required in patients with respiratory failure who fail NPPV, do not tolerate NPPV, or have contraindications to NPPV.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Both NPPV and invasive mechanical ventilation for patients with an acute exacerbation of COPD are discussed separately.

feed.title: Management of infection in acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

section.label: Viral infection
section.fragment: The most common viruses associated with exacerbations of COPD are rhinoviruses.

section.label: Viral infection
section.fragment: Identification of a virus in the sputum sample of a patient having a COPD exacerbation is relatively common and does not necessarily mean that this is the cause of the exacerbation.

section.label: Viral infection
section.fragment: In fact, such viruses have been found in up to 15 percent of asymptomatic individuals with stable COPD using sensitive PCR-based assays.

section.label: Viral infection
section.fragment: Viral infection of the airway epithelial cells induces inflammation.

section.label: Viral infection
section.fragment: This causes airway epithelial damage, muscarinic receptor stimulation, and induction of inflammatory mediators (eg, cytokines, chemokines).

section.label: Viral infection
section.fragment: Airway eosinophilia is associated with viral mediated exacerbations, which highlights the importance of the host response to infection and its impact on both inflammation and symptoms.

section.label: Bacterial infection
section.fragment: Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacteriaceae are also commonly isolated, particularly from patients with severe COPD.

section.label: Bacterial infection
section.fragment: This hypothesis is supported by the following observations: Exacerbations with new bacterial strains are more likely to be associated with a humoral immune response - In one study, exacerbations with a new strain of H. influenzae were significantly more likely to be associated with a humoral immune response than exacerbations with preexisting strains of H. influenzae (61 versus 21 percent).

section.label: Bacterial infection
section.fragment: Exacerbations with new bacterial strains are associated with a more robust inflammatory response - Exacerbations of COPD with a new strain of bacteria have been associated with more intense neutrophilic airway inflammation and systemic inflammation than exacerbations not associated with a change in preexisting bacterial strains or recovery of pathogenic bacteria.

section.label: Bacterial infection
section.fragment: In an animal model, new strains of H. influenzae that were known to be associated with COPD exacerbation caused significantly more airway neutrophil recruitment than colonizing strains of H. influenzae.

section.label: Bacterial infection
section.fragment: Most of the human studies were performed in patients with COPD who had chronic bronchitis because expectorated sputum could be obtained easily.

section.label: Bacterial infection
section.fragment: Thus, the degree to which the data can be generalized to exacerbations in patients with COPD who do not have chronic bronchitis is unknown.

section.label: Atypical bacteria
section.fragment: There are conflicting data regarding the incidence of atypical bacterial infection in patients having an exacerbation of COPD.

section.label: Atypical bacteria
section.fragment: The incidence of Chlamydophila pneumoniae in exacerbations of COPD appears to be 3 to 5 percent (Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Legionella spp are even more rare) if one considers only studies using rigorous methodology that excluded pneumonia and defined infection as a strict fourfold increase in titer or a positive culture.

section.label: Coinfection
section.fragment: Coinfection is increasingly being considered in studies looking at the pathogenesis of COPD exacerbation.

section.label: Coinfection
section.fragment: Such studies categorize exacerbations of COPD due to respiratory infection as being caused by viral infection alone, bacterial infection alone, or both.

section.label: Coinfection
section.fragment: In a similar study of outpatients, coinfection was associated with more symptoms, a larger fall in the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), higher bacterial loads, and systemic inflammation.

section.label: Sputum Gram stain and culture
section.fragment: Sputum Gram stain and cultures are often not useful for identifying bacterial infection in patients with COPD exacerbations for the following reasons: Gram stain and culture of expectorated sputum are similar during exacerbations and stable disease.

section.label: Sputum Gram stain and culture
section.fragment: In one study that collected sequential sputum cultures from patients with stable COPD, molecular typing revealed that apparently identical bacterial strains of H. influenzae were intermittently recovered, suggesting that false-negative culture results were common.

section.label: Sputum Gram stain and culture
section.fragment: A possible exception recognized by the GOLD guidelines is that sputum cultures may be helpful in patients who are strongly suspected of having a bacterial infection, but fail to respond to initial antibiotic therapy.

section.label: Risk factors for Pseudomonas
section.fragment: In contrast to H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis, and S. pneumoniae, Pseudomonas spp can easily be recovered from expectorated sputum obtained before initiating therapy.

section.label: Sputum purulence
section.fragment: Sputum purulence may be a marker of bacterial infection during an exacerbation of COPD.

section.label: Sputum purulence
section.fragment: In one bronchoscopic study of 40 patients with COPD exacerbations, more patients with purulent sputum had bronchial infection than patients with mucoid sputum (77 versus 6 percent).

section.label: Sputum purulence
section.fragment: Based on these observations, we believe that sputum purulence is an important, but not absolute, indicator of bacterial infection in patients with an exacerbation of COPD.

section.label: reactive protein
section.fragment: Procalcitonin is a peptide precursor of calcitonin that is released by parenchymal cells in response to bacterial toxins, leading to elevated serum levels in patients with bacterial infections;

section.label: reactive protein
section.fragment: in contrast, procalcitonin is down-regulated in patients with viral infections.

section.label: reactive protein
section.fragment: Procalcitonin has been evaluated to facilitate the decision of whether to use antibacterial agents in patients with acute respiratory tract infections and when antibiotics can be safely stopped.

section.label: reactive protein
section.fragment: In a 2012 Cochrane meta-analysis, procalcitonin guidance for antibiotic use was associated with a reduction in antibiotic exposure without an increase in mortality or treatment failure in any clinical setting (eg, outpatient clinic, emergency department) or in patients with any type of acute respiratory infection, including COPD exacerbation.

section.label: reactive protein
section.fragment: In a study of patients with acute exacerbations of COPD, procalcitonin showed poor concordance with sputum purulence, whereas another biomarker, C-reactive protein (CRP), correlated with sputum purulence.

section.label: reactive protein
section.fragment: Studies of procalcitonin and CRP in patients with community-acquired pneumonia are presented separately.

section.label: Rationale
section.fragment: The use of antibiotics in exacerbations of COPD is based on placebo-controlled trials and retrospective population studies that found that antibiotics improve clinical outcomes in many patients having an exacerbation of COPD.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: High-quality evidence from only the single trial described above showed a mortality benefit in critically ill patients.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: In the multivariate analysis of a retrospective cohort study that included 84,621 patients who were hospitalized patients with acute exacerbations of COPD, the risk of treatment failure was lower in those who received antibiotics during the first two hospital days compared with those who were treated later or not at all (odds ratio [OR] 0.87, 95% CI 0.82-0.92);

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: treatment failure was a composite endpoint defined as the initiation of mechanical ventilation after the second hospital day, inpatient mortality, or readmission for acute exacerbations of COPD within 30 days of discharge.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: Another study examined whether there is additive benefit of antibiotics over that provided by systemic glucocorticoids in the treatment of moderate to severe exacerbations in hospitalized patients not requiring mechanical ventilation.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: This may explain the substantial clinical failure rate of 39 percent at 30 days, even when patients received both antibiotics and glucocorticoids.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: A non-randomized prospective study was conducted in 73 patients with COPD exacerbations admitted to the hospital.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: If patients had purulent sputum, they received antibiotics;

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: Clinical outcomes were similar in the two groups.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: Whether antibiotics can be safely withheld from patients with acute exacerbations of COPD admitted to the hospital who do not have purulent sputum is an important question that needs to be addressed in a randomized trial.

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: The efficacy of antibiotics for COPD exacerbations is less well-established for outpatients than for inpatients.

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: Antibiotic therapy increased the likelihood of clinical improvement, defined as resolution of symptoms without additional intervention (68 versus 55 percent with placebo).

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: A randomized trial showed that amoxicillin-clavulanate administration for COPD exacerbations demonstrated both short- and long-term benefits in outpatients.

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: Median time to the next exacerbation was 233 days with amoxicillin-clavulanate compared to 166 days with placebo.

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: A population-based cohort study evaluated the risk of subsequent COPD exacerbations among nearly 19,000 outpatients treated for an exacerbation with oral glucocorticoids with or without antibiotics.

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: Median time to the second exacerbation was significantly longer among patients who received antibiotics plus oral glucocorticoids compared with those who received oral glucocorticoids alone (418 versus 321 days);

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: Mortality during follow-up was also lower in patients who received antibiotics (hazard ratio 0.82, 99% CI 0.66-0.98).

section.label: Outpatients
section.fragment: Clinical failure rates with moxifloxacin and amoxicillin-clavulanate were similar (21 versus 22 percent, respectively), demonstrating that both antibiotics are good choices outpatients with COPD exacerbations.

section.label: Indications
section.fragment: To try to maximize the benefit of antibiotic therapy, many clinical practice guidelines recommend antibiotic therapy only for those patients who are most likely to have bacterial infection or are most ill.

section.label: Indications
section.fragment: The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) guidelines, which are broader than the original Anthonisen criteria, recommend antibiotic therapy for patients who have the following features: a severe exacerbation requiring mechanical ventilation (noninvasive or invasive) or an exacerbation with increased sputum purulence plus either increased dyspnea or increased sputum volume.

section.label: Indications
section.fragment: We vary slightly from the GOLD guidelines in our clinical practices: We recommend antibiotics in patients with a moderate to severe COPD exacerbation, which is defined as having at least two of these three symptoms - increased dyspnea, increased sputum volume, or increased sputum purulence - or requiring hospitalization.

section.label: Indications
section.fragment: We do not initiate antibiotic therapy in patients whose exacerbation is mild, which we define as having only one of these three symptoms and not requiring hospitalization or ventilatory assistance (either invasive or noninvasive).

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: The optimal antibiotic regimen for the treatment of exacerbations of COPD has not been determined.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: Specifically, we prescribe a broader antibiotic regimen for patients who have risk factors for a poor outcome.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: This approach is illustrated in separate algorithms for selection of antibiotics in outpatients ) and inpatients.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: However, this approach has not been shown in prospective controlled trials to improve clinical outcomes.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: The initial antibiotic regimen should target likely bacterial pathogens (Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Streptococcus pneumoniae in most patients) and take into account local patterns of antibiotic resistance.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacteriaceae can occur in patients with severe COPD.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: Risk factors for P. aeruginosa infection are described above.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: However, amoxicillin is no longer considered a first-line agent because it is inactive against most nontypeable H. influenzae and M. catarrhalis.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: Other (ie, second-line) antibiotics are also logical choices for outpatients based upon in vitro activity and trials showing efficacy that is comparable, but usually not superior, to doxycycline and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: In patients with complicated COPD and risk factors for Pseudomonas who do not have indications for hospitalization, we suggest ciprofloxacin.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: The majority of patients with COPD exacerbations are treated as outpatients.

section.label: Choice of antibiotic
section.fragment: Hospitalized patients without risk factors for Pseudomonas can be treated with a respiratory fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin) or a third-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime).

section.label: Comparisons
section.fragment: Second-line antibiotics were significantly more likely than first-line antibiotics to achieve treatment success, defined as resolution or improvement of symptoms (OR 0.51, 95% CI 0.34-0.75).

section.label: Comparisons
section.fragment: A meta-analysis of 19 randomized trials (7405 patients with exacerbations of COPD) compared the effectiveness of macrolides, fluoroquinolones, and amoxicillin-clavulanate.

section.label: Comparisons
section.fragment: In a randomized trial that included 170 patients with acute exacerbations of COPD requiring mechanical ventilation, patients received a 10 day course of either trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or ciprofloxacin.

section.label: Comparisons
section.fragment: Hospital mortality and the need for additional antibiotic prescriptions were similar in both groups, indicating that trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole was non-inferior to ciprofloxacin.

section.label: Comparisons
section.fragment: For these reasons, we do not recommend either regimen for patients with severe COPD exacerbations requiring hospitalization.

section.label: Duration
section.fragment: The duration of antibiotic therapy for patients with a COPD exacerbation is usually three to seven days, depending upon the response to therapy.

section.label: Duration
section.fragment: A meta-analysis that compared five days to seven or more days of antimicrobial therapy (fluoroquinolones, cefixime, or clarithromycin) for exacerbations of COPD found no difference in outcome between the two groups, although there were fewer adverse events among patients who received a five-day course.

section.label: Duration
section.fragment: Patients who are initially started on parenteral antibiotics should be switched to an oral regimen when able to take medications orally.

section.label: Antiviral therapy
section.fragment: Patients whose COPD exacerbation was triggered by influenza virus should be treated with antiviral therapy according to current recommendations and based on the predicted susceptibility patterns of the circulating strains.

section.label: Vaccination
section.fragment: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) should receive influenza vaccine annually and pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine once, with a single booster five years later if the patient is >=65 years old and was less than 65 years old when the initial vaccination was given: The utility of influenza vaccine is well established for reducing both the rate and severity of symptoms due to influenza, including respiratory symptoms.

section.label: Vaccination
section.fragment: A meta-analysis of 11 trials, including six specifically performed in patients with COPD, found a significant reduction in the number of exacerbations per patient compared with placebo.

section.label: Vaccination
section.fragment: For pneumococcal vaccine, a meta-analysis of seven trials that assessed the effect on patients with COPD found no evidence of a significant impact on morbidity or mortality.

section.label: Vaccination
section.fragment: One trial provided data on acute exacerbations of COPD, with no significant effect of vaccination, and a second trial found no significant effect on hospitalizations for acute exacerbations.

section.label: Vaccination
section.fragment: The recommendation for the pneumococcal vaccine in patients with COPD is based upon studies suggesting a reduced frequency of pneumococcal pneumonia and pneumococcal bacteremia.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Some clinicians advocate prophylactic antibiotics for patients with severe exacerbations, especially those that occur seasonally.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Secondary outcomes of hospital admissions, change in lung function, serious adverse events, and mortality were not improved.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Two of the larger clinical trials included in the systematic review provide additional insight into the potential risks and benefits of prophylactic antibiotic therapy in carefully selected patients using newer antibiotic agents, and, in some cases, intermittent dosing regimens.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: In one such trial, 1157 patients with COPD at high risk for recurrent exacerbations were randomly assigned to receive either moxifloxacin or placebo;

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: The following observations were made: The patients who received moxifloxacin were less likely to have a COPD exacerbation in both the per-protocol analysis (OR 0.75, 95% CI 0.565-0.994) and in the intent-to-treat analysis (OR 0.81, 95% CI 0.645-1.008).

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: In another trial, a significant reduction in the frequency of COPD exacerbations was observed among patients who received azithromycin prophylaxis.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: In this trial, 1142 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to receive azithromycin 250 mg orally daily or placebo for one year in addition to their usual COPD regimen.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: The following findings were observed: The median time to first COPD exacerbation was significantly longer among the patients who received azithromycin compared with those who received placebo (266 versus 174 days).

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Patients who received azithromycin had a significant (but modest) reduction in the frequency of COPD exacerbations compared with those who received placebo (1.48 versus 1.83 exacerbations per patient-year; hazard ratio 0.73, 95% CI 0.63-0.84).

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Patients who received azithromycin had a significantly higher rate of nasopharyngeal colonization with macrolide-resistant bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus [S. aureus], Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus spp, Moraxella spp) than those who received placebo (81 versus 41 percent).

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: For most patients with COPD, we suggest not administering antibiotic prophylaxis.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Only carefully selected patients, such as those who continue to have frequent exacerbations in spite of optimal therapy for their COPD with bronchodilators and antiinflammatory agents, should be considered for antibiotic prophylaxis.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: In such patients, we suggest prophylaxis with azithromycin.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Suspected bacterial exacerbations in patients on antibiotic prophylaxis should be treated with antibiotics that are from a different class than the prophylactic agent.

section.label: Prophylactic antibiotics
section.fragment: Even if the regimen is successful in reducing exacerbations, interrupting treatment after 48 to 52 weeks should be considered.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: An exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is an acute increase in symptoms beyond normal day-to-day variation.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Most exacerbations of COPD are due to respiratory infection or environmental pollution.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Antibiotic therapy increases the likelihood of clinical improvement in patients having an exacerbation of COPD, particularly in patients with a moderate to severe exacerbation.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The optimal antibiotic regimen for the treatment of exacerbations of COPD has not been determined.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The initial antibiotic regimen should target likely bacterial pathogens and take into account local patterns of antibiotic resistance.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: The usual duration of antibiotic therapy is three to seven days, depending upon the response to therapy.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For most patients with COPD, we suggest not administering antibiotic prophylaxis.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: For patients who continue to have frequent exacerbations despite optimal therapy for COPD with bronchodilators and antiinflammatory agents, we suggest antibiotic prophylaxis with azithromycin.

feed.title: Role of systemic glucocorticoid therapy in COPD

section.label: RATIONALE
section.fragment: Both systemic and inhaled glucocorticoids are widely prescribed for patients with COPD.

section.label: RATIONALE
section.fragment: In part, the use of these agents in the management of COPD has been an extension of their use in asthma.

section.label: RATIONALE
section.fragment: In addition, this approach has been based on hypotheses that glucocorticoids might suppress inflammatory processes unique to COPD.

section.label: The asthma perspective
section.fragment: Although most experts regard asthma and COPD as distinct diseases, some patients with obstructive lung disease cannot be clearly categorized even after careful clinical evaluation.

section.label: Inflammation and COPD
section.fragment: Patients with COPD suffer from chronic destructive changes in the lungs, in addition to acute exacerbations.

section.label: Inflammation and COPD
section.fragment: The earliest lesion in smoking-related COPD may be chronic inflammation of distal airways, and inflammatory factors have also been proposed as a cause for some acute exacerbations.

section.label: CLINICAL EVIDENCE
section.fragment: The clinical value of systemic glucocorticoid therapy has been assessed both in patients with acute exacerbations, and in those with stable COPD.

section.label: Acute exacerbations
section.fragment: Two major systematic reviews combined the results of double blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trials of systemic glucocorticoids in patients with acute exacerbations of COPD.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: Randomized trials have demonstrated that patients hospitalized for COPD exacerbations benefit from systemic glucocorticoid therapy.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: However, examination of the data suggests that 10 to 14 day regimens of systemic glucocorticoid that begin with either a high or moderate dose can improve clinical outcomes.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: In this trial, 56 patients hospitalized for acute exacerbations were randomly assigned to receive either 30 mg of oral prednisolone or placebo daily for 14 days.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: The 10-day group had greater improvements in the primary endpoints of FEV1 and PaO2 and a small but statistically significant improvement in dyspnea on exertion.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: To address the same question in hospitalized patients with COPD, a non-superiority trial of 210 patients compared regimens of intravenous versus oral prednisolone, 60 mg once daily for five days, followed by oral prednisolone in all patients.

section.label: Hospitalized patients
section.fragment: A potential confounding factor was that the large majority of patients (77 percent) had been treated with oral glucocorticoids in the 30 days prior to admission, though post-hoc subgroup analyses suggested that this did not influence the results.

section.label: Outpatient exacerbations
section.fragment: Patients received oral prednisone (40 mg) or placebo for ten days.

section.label: Outpatient exacerbations
section.fragment: Patients who received prednisone were less likely to return to the emergency department or their clinician with increasing dyspnea within 30 days (27 versus 43 percent).

section.label: Outpatient exacerbations
section.fragment: All of the studies in acute exacerbations excluded patients who had recently used systemic glucocorticoids, which in some cases eliminated nearly one-half of all screened patients.

section.label: Stable COPD
section.fragment: Aside from the studies described above, most information on systemic glucocorticoids in outpatients with COPD has been derived from small, short-term studies in stable patients.

section.label: Stable COPD
section.fragment: Forty-six stable outpatients with COPD received either oral methylprednisolone (32 mg per day) or placebo for two weeks in a double blind, crossover trial.

section.label: Clinical implications of prednisone response
section.fragment: It appears unlikely that the response to a brief trial of oral glucocorticoids can predict which patients will have a more favorable response to chronic therapy with inhaled glucocorticoids.

section.label: Clinical implications of prednisone response
section.fragment: The change in FEV1 during a 14 day trial of systemic glucocorticoid therapy (0.6 mg per kg oral prednisolone per day) did not predict the change in FEV1 over three years of subsequent therapy with inhaled fluticasone.

section.label: Clinical implications of prednisone response
section.fragment: Another question is whether responsiveness to prednisone might help to predict prognosis in COPD.

section.label: Clinical implications of prednisone response
section.fragment: In a year long trial, investigators studied a group of patients with COPD who had a significant FEV1 response following a two-week course of prednisolone . These prednisolone "responders", all of whom were treated with inhaled budesonide (800 mcg/day), were compared to similar patients without a significant initial response to prednisolone.

section.label: Clinical implications of prednisone response
section.fragment: Despite continued efforts to study glucocorticoid responsiveness, definitive data on the role of glucocorticoid-response testing in COPD patients are lacking, perhaps due to the overall difficulty in assessing response or differences in patient populations tested.

section.label: Chronic therapy
section.fragment: Chronic daily doses of oral glucocorticoids have been prescribed for some patients.

section.label: Chronic therapy
section.fragment: There were no differences in exacerbations, spirometry, dyspnea, or health-related quality of life between the two groups during the six-month study, even though the demand group took considerably less prednisone than the continuous group.

section.label: term therapy and complications
section.fragment: There is a general perception that short-term therapy, even at high doses, is relatively innocuous, but these effects have not been fully studied in patients with COPD.

section.label: term therapy and complications
section.fragment: The SCCOPE trial was the first to prospectively evaluate a number of specific complications in COPD patients treated with glucocorticoids.

section.label: term therapy and complications
section.fragment: SCCOPE assessed the incidence of hyperglycemia, infections, hypertension, GI bleeding, and psychiatric disorders in patients treated with two-week and eight-week courses of systemic glucocorticoids.

section.label: term therapy and complications
section.fragment: Only hyperglycemia was more common in the glucocorticoid-treated groups, although part of the excess could be attributed to the fact that more diabetics were, by chance, assigned to the glucocorticoids groups.

section.label: term therapy and complications
section.fragment: The overall rate of infections observed in SCCOPE was no different among treatment groups, but patients who received the eight-week course of glucocorticoids had a tendency to have more severe infections, particularly pneumonia.

section.label: term therapy and complications
section.fragment: Other authors have reported severe infections related to immunosuppression in patients with COPD.

section.label: term therapy and complications
section.fragment: In addition, patients treated with short-term, high-dose glucocorticoids for septic shock have a significantly increased risk of secondary bacterial infection and an increased mortality.

section.label: Risks of chronic therapy
section.fragment: Prolonged courses of glucocorticoid therapy are generally thought to pose a greater risk for complications, particularly osteoporosis.

section.label: Risks of chronic therapy
section.fragment: Systemic glucocorticoid therapy has been shown to be associated with a greater number and severity of vertebral fractures in COPD patients.

section.label: Respiratory muscle dysfunction
section.fragment: Human subjects with autoimmune disease have developed significant reductions in inspiratory strength and endurance after eight weeks of high-dose prednisone . One study in patients with COPD admitted to the hospital for exacerbations suggested that higher average daily doses of glucocorticoids prior to hospitalization caused reductions in inspiratory and quadriceps muscle strength.

section.label: Respiratory muscle dysfunction
section.fragment: Although not conclusive, these data raise additional concerns about glucocorticoid treatment in COPD patients.

section.label: SUMMARY AND RECOMMENDATIONS
section.fragment: Overall, benefits in acutely ill patients are modest and benefits in stable patients are uncommon, reflecting COPD as a generally non-glucocorticoid-sensitive process that is distinct from asthma.

section.label: Acute exacerbations
section.fragment: Systemic glucocorticoids hasten recovery, reduce hospital stay, and reduce early treatment failure in patients with acute exacerbations of COPD.

section.label: Acute exacerbations
section.fragment: shorter courses may achieve adequate outcomes but need further study.

section.label: Acute exacerbations
section.fragment: Although the optimum initial daily dose remains to be determined, there is no reason to believe that intravenous therapy is better than oral therapy for patients who are able to take oral medication.

section.label: Acute exacerbations
section.fragment: While the above studies provide a rationale for treating all patients with COPD exacerbations with a short course of systemic glucocorticoids, data from SCCOPE would support some targeting of therapy based on prior hospitalizations, risk of adverse effects and clinical response.

section.label: Acute exacerbations
section.fragment: Selected outpatients with acute exacerbations may also benefit from a course of systemic glucocorticoids.

section.label: Stable COPD
section.fragment: Since not all patients with obstructive lung disease can be placed in precise subgroups of COPD or asthma, it is likely that glucocorticoids will always have a role in selected patients with COPD.

section.label: Stable COPD
section.fragment: By prescribing only a short course of systemic glucocorticoids when necessary for an individual exacerbation, applying some clinical skepticism in evaluating and treating "glucocorticoid-dependent" patients, and optimizing all other proven therapies, practitioners may be able to reduce the total systemic glucocorticoids exposure of COPD patients while achieving as good or better outcomes.

feed.title: Role of anticholinergic therapy in COPD

section.label: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
section.fragment: The most important of these naturally occurring alkaloids are atropine and scopolamine.

section.label: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
section.fragment: Atropa belladonna, the deadly nightshade, contains mainly the alkaloid atropine.

section.label: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
section.fragment: The alkaloid scopolamine (hyoscine) is found chiefly in the shrub Hyoscyamus niger (henbane) and Scopolia carniolica.

section.label: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
section.fragment: In 1867, Bezold and Bloebaum showed that atropine blocked the cardiac effects of vagal stimulation, and five years later Heidenhain found that it prevented salivary secretion produced by stimulation of the chorda tympani.

section.label: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
section.fragment: In 1859, it was reported that a severe asthma attack was successfully treated by injecting atropine into the vagus nerve.

section.label: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
section.fragment: inhalational and systemic preparations of atropine were soon available for the treatment of asthma.

section.label: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
section.fragment: With the introduction of ephedrine and epinephrine during the 20th century, the use of atropine and related substances for relief of bronchospasm declined.

section.label: PHYSIOLOGY AND PHARMACOLOGY
section.fragment: The bulk of autonomic nerves in the human airways are branches of the vagus nerve, whose efferent preganglionic fibers enter the lung at the hilum and travel along the airways into the lung.

section.label: PHYSIOLOGY AND PHARMACOLOGY
section.fragment: Acetylcholine (ACh) is the endogenous neurotransmitter at cholinergic nerve endings, and its actions are mediated through nicotinic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors.

section.label: Nicotinic receptors
section.fragment: Nicotinic receptors are located on ganglionic neurons and are activated by ACh released from preganglionic vagal fibers.

section.label: Nicotinic receptors
section.fragment: These receptors are stimulated by nicotinic agonists and inhibited by nicotinic antagonists like hexamethonium.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: Muscarinic receptors are found primarily on the autonomic effector cells that are innervated by postganglionic parasympathetic nerves.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: At least three of these are expressed in the lung : M1 receptors are present on peribronchial ganglion cells where the preganglionic nerves transmit to the postganglionic nerves.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: M2 receptors are present on the postganglionic nerves.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: M3 receptors are present on smooth muscle.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: Vagal fibers synapse and activate nicotinic and M1 muscarinic receptors in parasympathetic ganglia present in the airway wall.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: Short postganglionic fibers release ACh, which acts on M3 muscarinic receptors in airway smooth muscle.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: Atropine (the prototype of muscarinic receptor antagonists) prevents the effects of ACh by competitively blocking its binding to muscarinic receptors in the CNS, peripheral ganglia, and at neuroeffector sites on smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and secretory glands.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: Atropine inhibits secretions of the nose, mouth, pharynx, and bronchi and thus causes dryness of the mucous membranes of the respiratory tract.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: This depression of mucous secretion and the inhibition of mucociliary clearance, however, are undesirable side effects of atropine in patients with airway disease.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: Atropine is particularly effective against bronchoconstriction produced by parasympathomimetic drugs such as methacholine;

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: it also partially antagonizes bronchoconstriction induced by histamine and bradykinin.

section.label: Muscarinic receptors
section.fragment: As a result, extremely high doses of atropine or related drugs are required to produce any degree of blockade of the predominantly nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

section.label: TERTIARY VERSUS QUATERNARY AGENTS
section.fragment: Quaternary ammonium drugs (such as ipratropium) are synthetic derivatives of the naturally occurring tertiary ammonium compounds (such as atropine).

section.label: TERTIARY VERSUS QUATERNARY AGENTS
section.fragment: Other quaternary compounds include Oxitropium bromide (which is a derivative of scopolamine formed by the introduction of an ethyl group) and tiotropium bromide.

section.label: TERTIARY VERSUS QUATERNARY AGENTS
section.fragment: The structure of the quaternary ammonium compounds renders them freely soluble in water but insoluble in lipids;

section.label: TERTIARY VERSUS QUATERNARY AGENTS
section.fragment: Most of the pharmacologic properties that distinguish quaternary ammonium compounds from atropine are due to this feature: The tertiary ammonium compounds are lipid-soluble, easily absorbed, and can cause significant side effects, including tachycardia, dry mouth, flushing of the skin, blurred vision, and mood changes.

section.label: TERTIARY VERSUS QUATERNARY AGENTS
section.fragment: Unlike atropine, however, ipratropium lacks appreciable effect on the CNS, is poorly absorbed from the lungs or the gastrointestinal tract, and does not inhibit mucociliary clearance.

section.label: TERTIARY VERSUS QUATERNARY AGENTS
section.fragment: The use of ipratropium in patients with COPD therefore avoids the increased accumulation of lower airway secretions and the antagonism of beta-adrenergic agonist-induced enhancement of mucociliary clearance that is encountered with atropine.

section.label: IPRATROPIUM AS A SINGLE AGENT
